edition.title: The Tragedy of Arden of Faversham and Black Will

stagedir.dir: Arden and Franklin enter. Susan is in the background cleaning.

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: Arden, cheer up thy spirits and droop no more.
My gracious Lord the Duke of Somerset
Hath freely given to thee and to thy heirs.
By letters patents from His Majesty,
All the lands of the Abbey of Faversham.
Here are the deeds.
Sealed and subscribed with his name and the king’s.
Read them, and leave this melancholy mood.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Franklin, thy love prolongs my weary life,
And but for thee, how odious were this life
That shows me nothing but torments my soul.
And those foul objects that offend my eyes.
Which makes me wish that for this veil of heaven,
The earth hung over my head and covered me.
Love letters passed ’twixt Mosby and my wife,
And they have privy meetings in the town.
Nay, on his finger did I spy the ring
Which at our marriage day the priest put on.
Can any grief be half so great as this?

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: Comfort thyself, sweet friend: it is not strange.
That women will be false and wavering.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Ay, but to dote on such a one as he Is monstrous,
Franklin, and intolerable.

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: Why, what is he?

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: A butcher, and no better at the first,
Who, by base brokage getting some small stock,
Crept into service of a nobleman.
And by his servile flattery and fawning
Is now become the steward of his house
And bravely jets it in his silken gown.

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: No nobleman will count’nance such a peasant.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Yes, the Lord Clifford, he that loves not me.
But through his favor let not him grow proud.
For, were he by the Lord Protector backed,
He should not make me to be pointed at.
I am by birth a gentleman of blood.
And that injurious ribald that attempts
To violate my dear wife’s chastity,
(For dear I hold her love, as dear as heaven)
Shall, on the bed which he thinks to defile.
See his dissevered joints and sinews torn,
Whilst on the planchers pants his weary body,
Smeared in the channels of his lustful blood.

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: Be patient, gentle friend, and learn of me
To ease thy grief and save her chastity.
Entreat her fair: sweet words are fittest engines
To race the flint walls of a woman’s breast.
In any case, be not too jealous,
Nor make no question of her love to thee.
But as securely, presently take horse,
And lie with me at London all this term.
For women when they may, will not,
But being kept back, straight grow outrageous.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Though this abhors from reason, yet I’ll try it.
And call her forth, and presently take leave.
How, Alice!

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Husband, what mean you to get up so early?
Summer nights are short, and yet you rise ‘ere day.
Had I been ‘wake, you had not rise so soon.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Sweet love, thou knowst that we two, Ovid-like,
Have often chid the morning, when it ‘gan to peep.
And often wished that dark night’s purblind steeds
Would pull her by the purple mantle back
And cast her in the ocean to her love.
But this night, sweet Alice, thou hast killed my heart:
I heard thee call on Mosby in thy sleep.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: ‘Tis like I was asleep when I named him,
For being awake he comes not in my thoughts.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Ay, but you started up and suddenly.
Instead of him, caught me about the neck.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: “Instead of him?” Why, who was there but you,
And where but one is, how can I mistake?

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: Arden leave to urge her overfar.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Nay, love, there is no credit in a dream.
Let it suffice I know thou lov’st me well.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Now I remember whereupon it came:
Had we no talk of Mosby yesternight?

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: Mistress Alice, I heard you name him once or twice.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: And thereof came it, and therefore blame not me.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: I know it did, and therefore let it pass.
I must to London, sweet Alice, presently.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: But tell me, do you mean to stay there long?

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: No longer there till my affairs be done.

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: He will not stay above a month at most.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: A month? Ay mel Sweet Arden, come again
Within a day or two or else I die.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: I cannot long be from thee gentle Alice.
Whilst Michael fetch our horses from the field.
Franklin and I will down unto the quay,
For I have certain goods there to unload.
Meanwhile prepare our breakfast, gentle Alice.
For yet ‘ere noon we’ll take horse and away.

stagedir.dir: Alice exits the house, seeing them off.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Ere noon he means to take horse and away.
Sweet news is this. O, that some airy spirit
Would in the shape and likeness of a horse
Gallop with Arden ’cross the ocean
And throw him from his back into the waves.
Sweet Mosby is the man that hath my heart,
And he usurps it, having nought but this.
That I am tied to him by marriage.
Love is a god and marriage is but words,
And therefore, Mosby’s title is the best.
Tush! Whether it be or no, he shall be mine.
In spite of him, of Hymen, and of rites.
And here comes Adam of the Flower-de-Luce.
I hope he brings me tidings of my love.
How now Adam, what is the news with you?
Be not afraid, my husband is now from home.

speech.speaker: ADAM.
speech.line: He whom you wot of, Mosby, Mistress Alice,
Is come to town and sends you word by me.
In any case, you may not visit him.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Not visit him?

speech.speaker: ADAM.
speech.line: No, nor take no knowledge of his being here.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: But tell me, is he angry or displeased?

speech.speaker: ADAM.
speech.line: Should seem so, for he is wondrous sad.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Were he as mad as raving Hercules.
I’ll see him. Ay, and were thy house of force.
These hands of mine should raze it to the ground
Unless that thou wouldst bring me to my love.

speech.speaker: ADAM.
speech.line: Nay, and you be so impatient. I’ll be gone.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Stay, Adam, stay. Thou wert wont to be my friend.
Ask Mosby how I have incurred his wrath.
Bear him from me these pair of silver dice
With which we played for kisses many a time.
And when I lost, I won, and so did he.
Such winning and such losing Jove send me!
And bid him if his love do not decline.
Come this morning but along my door
And as a stranger but salute me there.
This may he do without suspect or fear.

speech.speaker: ADAM.
speech.line: I’ll tell him what you say, and so farewell.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Do, and one day I’ll make amends for all.
I know he loves me well but dares not come
Because my husband is so jealous,
And these my narrow, prying neighbors blab,
Hinder our meetings when we would confer.
But, if I live, that block shall be removed.
And Mosby, thou that comes to me by stealth,
Shalt neither fear the biting speech of men
Nor Arden’s looks. As surely shall he die.
As I abhor him, and love only thee.
How now Michael, whither are you going?

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: To fetch my master’s nag,
I hope you’ll think on me.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Ay, but Michael, see you keep your oath,
And be as secret as you are resolute.

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: I’ll see he shall not live above a week.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: On that condition, Michael, here is my hand.
None shall have Mosby’s sister but thyself.

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: I understand the painter here hard by
Hath made report that he and Sue is sure.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: There’s no such matter, Michael; believe it not.

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: But he hath sent a dagger sticking in a heart.
With a verse or two stolen from a painted book,
The which I hear the wench keeps in her chest.
Well let her keep it. I shall find a fellow
That can both write and read, and make rhyme too:
And if I do, well, I say no more.
I’ll send from London such a taunting letter
As shall eat the heart he sent with salt
And fling the dagger at the painter’s head.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: What needs all this? I say that Susan’s thine.

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: Why, then I say that I will kill my master
Or anything that you will have me do.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: But, Michael, see you do it cunningly.

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: Why, say I should be took, I’ll ne’er confess
That you know anything: and Susan, being a maid,
May beg me from the gallows of the shrieve.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Trust not to that, Michael.

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: You cannot tell me, I have seen it, I.
But mistress, tell her whether I live or die,
I’ll make her more worth than twenty painters can.
For I will rid mine elder brother away:
And then the farm of Bolton is mine own.
Who would not venture upon house and land
When he may have it for a right-down blow?

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Yonder comes Mosby, Michael get thee gone.
And let not him nor any know thy drifts.
Mosby, my love!

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Away I say, and talk not to me now.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: A word or two sweetheart, and then I will.
‘Tis yet but early days, thou need’st not fear.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Where is your husband?

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: ‘Tis now high water, and he is at the quay.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: There let him be. Henceforward know me not.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Is this the end of all thy solemn oaths?
Is this the fruit thy reconcilement buds?
Have I, for this, given thee so many favors,
Incurred my husband’s hate, and out alas,
Made shipwreck of mine honor for thy sake?
And dost thou say, “Henceforward know me not”?
Remember when I locked thee in my closet:
What were thy words and mine? Did we not both
Decree to murder Arden in the night?
The heavens can witness and the world can tell,
Before I saw that falsehood look of thine.
‘Fore I was tangled with thy ‘ticing speech,
Arden to me was dearer than my soul —
And shall be still. Base peasant, get thee gone!
And boast not of thy conquest over me.
Gotten by witchcraft, and mere sorcery.
For what hast thou to countenance my love.
Being descended of a noble house.
And matched already with a gentleman
Whose servant thou may’st be? And so farewell!

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Ungentle and unkind Alice, now I see
That which I ever feared and find too true:
A woman’s love is as the lightning flame
Which even in bursting forth consumes itself.
To try thy constancy have I been strange.
Would I had never tried, but lived in hope.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: What needs thou try me whom thou never found false?

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Yet pardon me, for love is jealous.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: So list the sailor to the mermaid’s song:
So looks the traveller to the basilisk.
I am content for to be reconciled.
And that I know will be mine overthrow.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Thine overthrow? First let the world dissolve!

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Nay, Mosby, let me still enjoy thy love.
And, happen what will, I am resolute.
My saving husband hordes up bags of gold
To make our children rich, and now is he
Gone to unload the goods that shall be thine,
And he and Franklin will to London straight.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: To London, Alice? If thou’lt be ruled by me,
We’ll make him sure enough for coming there.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Ah, would we could!

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: I happened on a painter yesternight,
The only cunning man of Christendom,
For he can temper poison with his oil
That who so looks upon the work he draws
Shall, with the beams that issue from his sight,
Suck venom to his breast and slay himself.
Sweet Alice, he shall draw thy counterfeit
That Arden, may by gazing on it, perish.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Ay, but Mosby, that is dangerous,
For thou, or I, or any other else,
Coming into the chamber where it hangs, may die.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Ay, but we’ll have it covered with a cloth.
And hung up in the study for himself.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: It may not be, for when the picture’s drawn,
Arden, I know, will come and show it me.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Fear not: we’ll have that shall serve the turn.
This is the painter’s house: I’ll call him forth.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: But Mosby, I’ll have no such picture, I.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Ay, pray thee leave it to my discretion. How, Clarke!
O, you are an honest man of your word: you served me well.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Why sir, I’ll do it for you at any time.
Provided, as you have given your word,
I may have Susan Mosby to my wife.
For as sharp-witted poets, whose sweet verse
Make heavenly gods break off their nectar draughts
And lay their ears down to the lowly earth.
Use humble promise to their sacred Muse,
So we that are the poets’ favorites
Must have a love. Ay, love is the painter’s Muse.
That makes him frame a speaking countenance,
A weeping eye that witnesses heart’s grief.
Then tell me, Master Mosby, shall I have her?

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: ’Tis pity but he should: he’ll use her well.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Clarke here’s my hand: my sister shall be thine.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Then, brother, to requite this courtesy,
You shall command my life, my skill and all.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Ah, that thou could’st be secret!

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Fear him not. Leave: I have talked sufficient.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: You know not me, that ask such questions.
Let it suffice I know you love him well
And fain would have your husband made away,
Wherein, trust me, you show a noble mind,
That rather than you’ll live with him you hate
You’ll venture life, and die with him you love.
The like will I do for my Susan’s sake.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Yet nothing could enforce me to the deed
But Mosby’s love. Might I without control
Enjoy thee still, then Arden should not die:
But seeing I cannot, therefore let him die.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Enough, sweet Alice. Thy kind words makes me melt.
Your trick of poisoned pictures we dislike:
Some other poison would do better far.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Ay, such as might be put into his broth.
And yet in taste not to be found at all.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: I know your mind, and here I have it for you.
Put but a dram of this into his drink.
Or any kind of broth that he shall eat.
And he shall die within an hour after.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: As I am a gentlewoman, Clarke, next day
Thou and Susan shall be married.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: And I’ll make her dowry more than I’ll talk of, Clarke.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Yonder’s your husband: Mosby. I’ll be gone.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: In good time — see where my husband comes!

stagedir.dir: Thomas Arden, Franklin, and Michael enter.

speech.line: Master Mosby, ask him the question yourself.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Master Arden, being at London yesternight.
The Abbey lands whereof you are now possessed
Were offered me on some occasion
By Greene, one of Sir Antony Ager’s men.
I pray you sir, tell me, are not the lands yours?
Hath any other interest herein?

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Mosby, that question we’ll decide anon.
Alice, make ready my breakfast: I must hence.
As for the lands, Mosby, they are mine,
By letters patents from His Majesty.
But I must have a mandate for my wife:
They say you seek to rob me of her love.
Villain, what makes thou in her company?
She’s no companion for so base a groom.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Arden, I thought not on her. I came to thee.
But rather than I pocket up this wrong—

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: What will you do, sir?

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Revenge it on the proudest of you both.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: So, sirrah, you may not wear a sword.
The statute makes against artificers:
I warrant that I do. Now use your bodkin.
Your Spanish needle and your pressing iron.
For this shall go with me, and mark my words.
You, goodman butcher, ’tis to you I speak.
The next time that I take thee near my house,
Instead of legs, I’ll make thee crawl on stumps.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Ah, Master Arden, you have injured me.
I do appeal to God and to the world.

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: Why can’st thou deny thou wert a butcher once?

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Measure me what I am, not what I was.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Why what art thou now, but a velvet drudge,
A cheating steward, and base-minded peasant?

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Arden, now thou hast belched and vomited
The rancorous venom of thy mis-swoll’n heart,
Hear me but speak. As I intend to live
With God and his elected saints in heaven,
I never meant more to solicit her:
And that she knows, and all the world shall see,
I loved her once. Sweet Arden, pardon me.
I could not choose: her beauty fired my heart.
But time hath quenched these overraging coals:
And Arden, though I now frequent thy house,
‘Tis for my sister’s sake, her waiting-maid.
And not for hers. Mayst thou enjoy her long.
Hell fire and wrathful vengeance light on me
If I dishonor her or injure thee.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Mosby, with these thy protestations.
The deadly hatred of my heart is appeased,
And thou and I’ll be friends, if this prove true.
As for the base terms I gave thee late,
Forget them, Mosby. I had cause to speak
When all the knights and gentlemen of Kent
Make common table talk of her and thee.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Who lives that is not touched with sland’rous tongues?

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: Then Mosby, to eschew the speech of men,
Upon whose general bruit all honor hangs,
Forbear his house.

stagedir.dir: Arden returns Mosby’s sword to him.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Forbear it, nay rather frequent it more:
The world shall see that I distrust her not.
To warn him on the sudden from my house
Were to confirm the rumor that is grown.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: By faith, my sir, you say true.
And therefore will I sojourn here a while,
Until our enemies have talked their fill.
And then I hope they’ll cease, and at last confess
How causeless they have injured her and me.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: And I will lie at London all this term
To let them see how light I weigh their words.

stagedir.dir: Alice enters, placing breakfast on the table.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Husband, sit down; your breakfast will be cold.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.

stagedir.dir: They return to the dining area.

speech.line: Come, Master Mosby, will you sit with us.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: I cannot eat, but I’ll sit for company.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Sirrah Michael, see our horse be ready.

stagedir.dir: Arden starts to eat a few times, but keeps pausing, distracted, before he takes a bite.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Husband, why pause ye, why eat you not?

stagedir.dir: Arden finally takes a small taste.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: I am not well: there’s something in this broth
That is not wholesome. Didst thou make it, Alice?

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: I did, and that’s the cause it likes not you.

stagedir.dir: She throws down the broth on the ground.

speech.line: There’s nothing that I do can please your taste:
You were best to say I would have poisoned you.
I cannot speak or cast aside my eye
But he imagines I have stepped awry.
Here’s he that you cast in my teeth so oft.
Now will I be convinced or purge myself.
I charge thee speak to this mistrustful man—
Thou that wouldst see me hang, thou, Mosby thou.
What favor hast thou had more than a kiss
At coming or departing from the town?

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: You wrong yourself and me to cast these doubts:
Your loving husband is not jealous.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Why, gentle Mistress Alice, cannot I be ill
But you’ll accuse yourself?
Franklin, thou hast a box of mithridate,
I’ll take a little to prevent the worst.

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: Do so, and let us presently take horse:
My life for yours, ye shall do well enough.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Give me a spoon. I’ll eat of it myself.
Would it were full of poison to the brim,
Then should my cares and troubles have an end.
Was ever silly woman so tormented?

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Be patient, sweet love: I mistrust not thee.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: God will revenge it, Arden, if thou dost:
For never woman loved her husband better than I do thee.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: I know it, sweet Alice, cease to complain:
Lest that in tears I answer thee again.

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: Come, leave this dallying and let us away.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Forbear to wound me with that bitter word:
Arden shall go to London in my arms.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Loath am I to depart: yet I must go.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Wilt thou to London then, and leave me here?
Ah, if thou love me, gentle Arden, stay:
Yet, if thy business be of great import,
Go if thou wilt. I’ll bear it as I may.
But write from London to me every week.
Nay, everyday and stay no longer there
Than thou must needs, lest that I die for sorrow.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: I’ll write unto thee every other tide.
And so farewell, sweet Alice, till we meet next.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Farewell, husband, seeing you’ll have it so.
And Master Franklin, seeing you take him hence
In hope you’ll hasten him home I’ll give you this.

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: And if he stay, the fault shall not be mine.—
Mosby, farewell, and see you keep your oath.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: I hope he is not jealous of me now.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: No, Mosby, no. Hereafter think of me
As of your dearest friend, and so, farewell.

stagedir.dir: Alice and Mosby see them off.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: I am glad he is gone: he was about to stay.
But did you mark me then how I break off?

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Ay, Alice, and it was cunningly performed:
But what a villain is this painter Clarke?

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Was it not a goodly poison that he gave!
Why he’s as well now as he was before.
It should have been some fine confection
That might have given the broth some dainty taste.
This powder was too gross and populous.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: But had he eaten but three spoonfuls more,
Then had he died and our love continued.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Why, so it shall Mosby, albeit he live.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: It is impossible, for I have sworn
Never hereafter to solicit thee,
Or whilst he lives, once more importune thee.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Thou shalt not need: I will importune thee.
What, shall an oath make thee forsake my love?
As if I have not sworn as much myself
And given my hand unto him in the church.
Tush, Mosby, oaths are words, and words is wind,
And wind is mutable. Then, I conclude.
’Tis childishness to stand upon an oath.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Well proved, Mistress Alice, yet by your leave.
I’ll keep mine unbroken whilst he lives.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Ay, do, and spare not, his time is but short:
For, if thou best as resolute as I,
We’ll have him murdered as he walks the streets.
In London many ale-house ruffians keep,
Which as I hear will murder men for gold,
They shall be soundly fee’d to pay him home.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Alice, what’s he that comes yonder, knowst thou him?

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Mosby, be gone: I hope ’tis one that comes
To put in practice our intended drifts.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Mistress Arden, you are well met.
I am sorry that your husband is from home
When as my purposed journey was to him.
Yet all my labor is not spent in vain.
For I suppose that you can full discourse
And flat resolve me of the thing I seek.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: What is it, Master Greene? If that I may
Or can with safety, I will answer you.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: I heard your husband hath the grant of late,
Confirmed by letters patents from the king.
Of all the lands of the Abbey of Faversham.
Generally entitled, so that all former grants
Are cut off, whereof I myself had one,
But now my interest by that is void.
This is all, Mistress Arden: is it true nor no?

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: True, Master Greene, the lands are his in state:
And whatsoever leases were before
Are void for term of Master Arden’s life.
He hath the grant under the Chancery seal.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Pardon me, Mistress Arden: I must speak.
For I am touched. Your husband doth me wrong
To wring me from the little land I have.
My living is my life, only that
Resteth remainder of my portion.
Desire of wealth is endless in his mind,
And he is greedy-gaping still for gain:
Nor cares he though young gentlemen do beg,
So he may scrape and horde up in his pouch.
But seeing he hath taken my lands, I’ll value life
As careless, as he is careful for to get:
And tell him this from me, I’ll be revenged.
And so, as he shall wish the Abbey lands
Had rested still within their former state.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Alas, poor gentleman, I pity you:
And woe is me that any man should want.
God knows ’tis not my fault: but wonder not
Though he be hard to others, when to me,
Ah, Master Greene, God knows how I am used.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Why, Mistress Arden, can the crabbed churl
Use you unkindly? Respects he not your birth,
Your honorable friends, nor what you brought?
Why, all Kent knows your parentage, and what you are.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Ah, Master Greene, be it spoken in secret here.
I never live good day with him alone.
When he is at home, then have I froward looks,
Hard words and blows, to mend the match withal.
And, though I might content as good a man.
Yet doth he keep in every corner trulls.
And, weary with his trugs at home,
Then rides he straight to London. There, forsooth.
He revels it among such filthy ones
As counsels him to make away his wife:
Thus live I daily in continual fear.
In sorrow, so despairing of redress
As every day I wish with hearty prayer,
That he or I were taken forth the world.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Now trust me, Mistress Alice, it grieveth me
So fair a creature should be so abused.
Why, who would have thought the civil sir so sullen?
He looks so smoothly now. Fie upon him churl!
And if he live a day, he lives too long.
But frolic, woman: I shall be the man
Shall set you free from all this discontent.
And if the churl deny my interest
And will not yield my lease into my hand,
I’ll pay him home, whatever hap to me.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: But speak you as you think?

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Ay, God’s my witness, I mean plain dealing:
For I had rather die than lose my land.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Then, Master Greene, be counsellèd by me:
Endanger not yourself for such a churl,
But hire some cutter for to cut him short.
And here’s ten pound, to wager them withal.
When he is dead you shall have twenty more:
And the lands whereof my husband is possessed
Shall be entitled as they were before.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Will you keep promise with me?

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Or count me false and perjured whilst I live.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Then here’s my hand I’ll have him so dispatched.
I’ll up to London straight: I’ll thither post
And never rest till I have compassed it.
Till then, farewell.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Good fortune follow all your forward thoughts.
And whosoever doth attempt the deed,
A happy hand I wish and so farewell.
All this goes well. Mosby, I long for thee
To let thee know all that I have contrived.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: How now Alice, what’s the news?

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Such as will content thee well, sweetheart.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Well, let them pass awhile, and tell me, Alice.
How have you dealt and tempered with my sister?
What, will she have my neighbor Clarke or no?

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: What, Master Mosby, let him woo himself.
Think you that maids look not for fair words?
Go to her, Clarke: she’s all alone within.
Michael, my man, is clean out of her books.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: I thank you, Mistress Arden, I will in.
And, if fair Susan and I can make a gree,
You shall command me to the uttermost,
As far as either goods or life may stretch.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Now, Alice, let’s hear thy news?

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: They be so good that I must laugh for joy
Before I can begin to tell my tale.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Let’s hear them, that I may laugh for company.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: This morning, Master Greene — Dick Greene, I mean,
From whom my husband had the Abbey land —
Came hither railing for to know the truth
Whether my husband had the lands by grant.
I told him all, whereat he stormed amain,
And swore he would cry quittance with the churl:
And if he did deny his interest,
Stab him, whatsoever did befall himself.
When as I saw his choler thus to rise,
I whetted on the gentleman with words
And to conclude, Mosby, at last we grew
To composition for my husband’s death.
I gave him ten pound to hire knaves
By some device to make away the churl.
When he is dead, he should have twenty more
And repossess his former lands again.
On this we greed and he is ridden straight
To London to bring his death about.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: But call you this good news?

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Ay, sweetheart, be they not?

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: ’Twere cheerful news, to hear the churl were dead.
But trust me Alice, I take it passing ill
You would be so forgetful of our state
To make recount of it to every groom.
What, to acquaint each stranger with our drifts,
Chiefly in case of murder! Why, ’tis the way
To make it open unto Arden’s self
And bring thyself and me to ruin both.
Forewarned, forearmed, who threats his enemy
Lends him a sword to guard himself withal.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: I did it for the best.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Well, seeing ’tis done, cheerily let it pass.
You know this Greene, is he not religious.
A man I guess of great devotion?

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: He is.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Then, sweet Alice, let it pass. I have a drift
Will quiet all, whatever is amiss.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: How now, Clarke, have you found me false?
Did I not plead the matter hard for you?

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: You did.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: And what, will’t be a match?

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: A match, i’ faith, sir. Ay, the day is mine.
The painter lays his colors to the life,
His pencil draws no shadows in his love.
Susan is mine.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: You make her blush.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: What, sister, is it Clarke must be the man?

speech.speaker: SUS.
speech.line: It resteth in your grant. Some words are passed
And happily we be grown unto a match
If you be willing that it shall be so?

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Ah, Master Clarke, it resteth at my grant.
You see my sister’s yet at my dispose.
But so you’ll grant me one thing, I shall ask,
I am content my sister shall be yours.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: What is it, Master Mosby?

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: I do remember once in secret talk
You told me how you could compound by art
A crucifix empoisonèd.
That who so look upon it should wax blind.
And with the scent be stifled, that ‘ere long,
He should die poisoned that did view it well.
I would have you make me such a crucifix,
And then I’ll grant my sister shall be yours.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Though I am loath because it toucheth life,
Yet, rather ‘ere I’ll leave sweet Susan’s love,
I’ll do it, and with all the haste I may.
But for whom is it?

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Leave that to us. Why, Clarke, is it possible
That you should paint and draw it out yourself,
The colors being baleful and empoisoned,
And no ways prejudice yourself withal?

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Well questioned, Alice.— Clarke, how answer you that?

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Very easily. I’ll tell you straight,
How I do work of these empoisoned drugs.
I fasten on my spectacles so close
As nothing can any way offend my sight.
Then as I put a leaf within my nose,
So put I rhubarb to avoid the smell,
And, softly as another work, I paint.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: ’Tis very well, but against when shall I have it?

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Within this ten days.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: ’Twill serve the turn.
Now, Alice, let’s in and see what cheer you keep:
I hope, now Master Arden is from home,
You’ll give me leave to play your husband’s part.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Mosby, you know who’s master of my heart.
He well may be the master of the house.

speech.speaker: BRAD.
speech.line: See you them that comes yonder, Master Greene?

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Ay, very well: do you know them?

speech.speaker: BRAD.
speech.line: The one I know not: but he seems a knave.
Chiefly for bearing the other company.
For such a slave, so vile a rogue as he,
Lives not again upon the earth,
Black Will is his name. I tell you Master Greene,
At Boulogne he and I were fellow soldiers.
Where he played such pranks.
As all the camp feared him for his villainy.
I warrant you he bears so bad a mind
That for a crown he’ll murder any man.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: The fitter is he for my purpose, marry.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: How now, fellow Bradshaw,
Whither away so early?

speech.speaker: BRAD.
speech.line: O Will, times are changed, no fellows now,
Though we were once together in the field.
Yet, thy friend to do thee any good I can.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Why, Bradshaw, was not thou and I fellow soldiers at Boulogne, where I was a corporal and thou but a base mercenary groom? “No fellows now,” because you are a goldsmith and have a little plate in your shop. You were glad to call me “fellow Will,” and with a curtsy to the earth, “One snatch good corporal” when I stole the half ox from John the victualler and domineered with it amongst good fellows in one night.

speech.speaker: BRAD.
speech.line: Ay, Will, those days are past with me.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Ay, but they be not past with me, for I keep that same honorable mind still. Good neighbor Bradshaw, you are too proud to be my fellow. But were it not that I see more company coming down the hill, I would be fellows with you once more, and share crowns with you too. But let that pass, and tell me whither you go.

speech.speaker: BRAD.
speech.line: To London, Will, about a piece of service
Wherein happily thou mayst pleasure me.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: What is it?

speech.speaker: BRAD.
speech.line: Of late, Lord Cheyne lost some plate,
Which one did bring, and sold it at my shop,
Saying he served Sir Anthony Cooke,
A search was made, the plate was found with me,
And I am bound to answer at the court.
Now Lord Cheyne solemnly vows
If law will serve him, he’ll hang me for this theft.
Now I am going to London upon hope,
To find the fellow. Now, Will, I know
Thou art acquainted with such companions.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: What manner of man was he?

speech.speaker: BRAD.
speech.line: A lean-faced, writhen knave.
Hawk-nosed, and very hollow-eyed.
With mighty furrows in his stormy brows,
Long hair down his shoulders curled:
His chin was bare, but on his upper lip,
A mutchado, which he wound about his ear.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: What apparel had he?

speech.speaker: BRAD.
speech.line: A watchet satin doublet all to-torn:
The inner side did bear the greater show:
A pair of threadbare velvet hose, seam rent,
A worsted stocking rent above the shoe,
A livery cloak, but all the lace was off.
’Twas bad, but yet it served to hide the plate.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Sirrah Shakebag, canst thou remember since we trolled the bowl at Sittingburgh, where I broke the tapster’s head of the Lion with a cudgel-stick?

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: Ay, very well, Will.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Why, it was with the money that the plate was sold for. Sirrah Bradshaw what wilt thou give him that can tell thee who sold thy plate?

speech.speaker: BRAD.
speech.line: Who? I pray thee, good Will.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Why ’twas one Jack Fitten. He’s now in Newgate for stealing a horse, and shall be arraigned the next ’size.

speech.speaker: BRAD.
speech.line: Why then, let Lord Cheyne seek Jack Fitten forth, for I’ll back and tell him who robbed him of his plate. This cheers my heart.— Master Greene, I’ll leave you, for I must to the Isle of Sheppey with speed.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Before you go, let me entreat you to carry this letter to Mistress Arden of Faversham and humbly recommend me to herself.

speech.speaker: BRAD.
speech.line: That will I, Master Greene, and so farewell.
Here, Will, there’s a crown for thy good news.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Farewell, Bradshaw, I’ll drink no water for thy sake, whilst this lasts. Now gentleman, shall we have your company to London?

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Nay, stay sirs, a little more I needs must use your help.
And in a matter of great consequence,
Wherein, if you’ll be secret and profound,
I’ll give you twenty angels for your pains.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: How? Twenty angels? Give my fellow George Shakebag and me twenty angels, and if thou’lt have thy own father slain, that thou mayst inherit his land, we’ll kill him.

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: Ay, thy mother, thy sister, thy brother, or all thy kin.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Well, this it is: Arden of Faversham
Hath highly wronged me about the Abbey land.
That no revenge but death will serve the turn.
Will you two kill him? Here’s the angels down,
And I will lay the platform of his death.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Plat me no platforms! Give me the money, and I’ll stab him as he stands pissing against a wall—I’ll kill him.

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: Where is he?

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: He is now at London, in Aldersgate Street.

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: He’s dead, as if he had been condemned by an act of Parliament, if once Black Will and I swear his death.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Here is twenty pound, and when he is dead,
Ye shall have forty more.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: My fingers itches to be at the peasant. Ah, that I might be set a work thus through the year, and that murder would grow to an occupation that a man might without danger of law. Zounds, I warrant I should be warden of the company. Come let us be going, and we’ll bait at Rochester, where I’ll give thee a gallon of sack to handsel the match withal.

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: I have gotten such a letter.
As will touch the painter, and thus it is:

stagedir.dir: Arden and Franklin enter quietly and listen as Michael reads the letter:

line.recite: “My duty remembered Mistress Susan, hoping in God you be in good health, as I, Michael, was at the making hereof. This is to certify you, that as the turtle true, when she hath lost her mate, sitteth alone, so I mourning for your absence, do walk up and down Paul’s, till one day I fell asleep and lost my master’s pantofles. Ah, Mistress Susan, abolish that paltry painter: cut him off by the shins with a frowning look of your crabbed countenance and think upon Michael, who, drunk with the dregs of your favor, will cleave as fast to your love, as a plaster of pitch to a galled horseback. Thus hoping you will let my passions penetrate, or rather impetrate mercy of your meek hands, I end.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Why, you paltry knave,
Stand you here loitering, knowing my affairs.
What haste my business craves to send to Kent?

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: Faith, friend Michael, this is very ill.
Knowing your master hath no more but you.
And do ye slack his business for your own?

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Where is the letter, sirrah, let me see it.
See Master Franklin, here’s proper stuff:
Susan, my maid, the painter, and my man,
A crew of harlots all in love forsooth.—
Sirrah, let me hear no more of this.
Now for thy life, once write to her a word.

stagedir.dir: Greene, Will, and Shakebag enter, unseen by the others.

speech.line: Wilt thou be married to so base a whore?
‘Tis Mosby’s sister! Once I come at home,
I’ll rout her from remaining in my house.
Now, Master Franklin, let us go walk in Paul’s.
Come, but a turn or two and then away.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: The first is Arden, and that’s his man,
The other is Franklin, Arden’s dearest friend.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Zounds! I’ll kill them all three!

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Nay, sirs, touch not his man in any case:
But stand close, and take you fittest standing.
And at his coming forth speed him,
To the Nag’s Head: there is this coward’s haunt.
But now I’ll leave you till the deed be done.

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: If he be not paid his own, ne’er trust Shakebag.

stagedir.dir: They see Arden, Franklin, and Michael returning.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Sirrah Shakebag, at his coming forth I’ll run him through, and then to the Blackfriars, and there take water and away.

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: Why that’s the best, but see thou miss him not.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: How can I miss him, when I think on the forty angels I must have more.

speech.speaker: PRE.
speech.line: ‘Tis very late. I were best shut up my stall, for here will be old filching when the press comes forth of Paul’s.

stagedir.dir: Then lets he down his window, and it breaks Black Will’s head.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Zounds! Draw, Shakebag, draw! I am almost killed!

speech.speaker: PRE.
speech.line: We’ll tame you, I warrant.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Zounds, I am tame enough already.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: What troublesome fray or mutiny is this?

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: ‘Tis nothing but some brabbling paltry fray,
Devised to pick men’s pockets in the throng.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Is’t nothing else? Come, Franklin, let us away.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: What mends shall I have for my broken head?

speech.speaker: PRE.
speech.line: Marry, this mends, that if you get you not away all the sooner, you shall be well beaten and sent to the Counter.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Well, I’ll be gone: but look to your signs. For I’ll pull them down all. Shakebag, my broken head grieves me not so much, as by this means Arden hath escaped.
I had a glimpse of him and his companion.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Why, sirs, Arden’s as well as I.
I met him and Franklin going merrily to the ordinary.
What, dare you not do it?

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Yes, sir, we dare do it, but were my consent to give again. We would not do it under ten pound more. I value every drop of my blood at a French crown. I have had ten pound to steal a dog: and we have no more here to kill a man. But that a bargain is a bargain, and so forth, you should do it yourself.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: I pray thee how came thy head broke?

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Why, thou see’st it is broke, dost thou not?

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: Standing against a stall, watching Arden’s coming.
A boy let down his shop window and broke his head,
Whereupon arose a brawl and in the tumult
Arden escaped us, and passed by unthought on.
But forbearance is no acquittance.
Another time we’ll do it, I warrant thee.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: I pray thee, Will, make clean thy bloody brow,
And let us bethink us on some other place,
Where Arden may be met with handsomely.
Remember how devoutly thou hast sworn
To kill the villain: think upon thine oath.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Tush, I have broken five hundred oaths,
But wouldst thou charm me to effect this deed?
Tell me of gold my resolution’s fee.
Say thou see’st Mosby kneeling at my knees.
Off’ring me service for my high attempt:
And sweet Alice Arden with a lap of crowns
Comes with a lowly curtsy to the earth
Saying, “Take this, but for thy quarterage,
Such yearly tribute will I answer thee.”
Why this would steel soft-mettled cowardice.
With which Black Will was never tainted with.
I tell thee, Greene, the forlorn traveller.
Whose lips are glued with summer’s parching heat.
Ne’er longed so much to see a running brook,
As I to finish Arden’s tragedy.
See’st thou this gore that cleaveth to my face?
From hence ne’er will I wash this bloody stain.
Till Arden’s heart be panting in my hand.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Why, that’s well said, but what saith Shakebag?

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: I cannot paint my valor out with words,
But give me place and opportunity:
Such mercy as the starven lioness
When she is dry sucked of her eager young
Shows to the prey that next encounters her,
On Arden so much pity would I take.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: So should it fare with men of firm resolve.
And now, sirs, seeing this accident
Of meeting him in Paul’s hath no success.
Let us bethink us on some other place,
Whose earth may swallow up this Arden’s blood.
See yonder comes his man, and wot you what?
The foolish knave is in love with Mosby’s sister,
And for her sake, whose love he cannot get
Unless Mosby solicit his suit,
The villain hath sworn the slaughter of his master.
We’ll question him, for he may stead us much.
How now, Michael, whither are you going?

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: My master hath new supped: and I am going to prepare his chamber.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Where supped Master Arden?

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: At the Nag’s Head, at the eighteenpence ordinary. How now, Master Shakebag. What, Black Will? God’s dear Lady, how chance your face is so bloody?

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Go to, sirrah, there is a chance in it. This sauciness in you will make you be knocked.

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: Nay, and you be offended: I’ll be gone.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Stay, Michael: you may not ‘scape us so.
Michael, I know you love your master well.

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: Why so I do, but wherefore urge you that?

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Because I think you love your mistress better.

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: So think not I. But say, i’ faith, what if I should?

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: Come to the purpose.— Michael, we hear
You have a pretty love in Faversham.

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: Why, have I two or three, what’s that to thee?

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: You deal too mildly with the peasant. Thus it is.
‘Tis known to us you love Mosby’s sister.
We know, besides, that you have ta’en your oath
To further Mosby to your mistress’ bed,
And kill your master for his sister’s sake.
Now sir, a poorer coward than yourself
Was never fostered in the coast of Kent.
How comes it then, that such a knave as you
Dare swear a matter of such consequence?

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Ah, Will—

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Tush give me leave, there’s no more but this.
Sith thou hast sworn, we dare discover all:
And hadst thou or shouldst thou utter it,
We have devised a complot underhand,
Whatever shall betide to any of us,
To send thee roundly to the devil of hell.
And therefore thus, I am the very man.
Marked in my birth hour by the Destinies,
To give an end to Arden’s life on earth.
Thou but a member, but to whet the knife,
Whose edge must search the closet of his breast,
Thy office is but to appoint the place
And train thy master to his tragedy:
Mine to perform it when occasion serves.
Then be not nice, but here devise with us
How and what way we may conclude his death.

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: So shalt thou purchase Mosby for thy friend
And by his friendship gain his sister’s love.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: So shall thy mistress be thy favorer,
And thou disburdened of the oath thou made.

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: Well, gentlemen, I cannot but confess.
Since you have urged me so apparently,
That I have vowed my Master Arden’s death:
And he whose kindly love and liberal hand,
Doth challenge nought but good deserts of me,
I will deliver over to your hands.
This night come to his house at Aldersgate.
The doors I’ll leave unlocked for when you come.
No sooner shall ye enter through the latch,
Over the threshold to the inner court
But on your left hand shall you see the stairs
That leads directly to my master’s chamber.
There take him and dispose him as ye please.
Now, it were good we parted company:
What I have promised, I will perform.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Should you deceive us, ’twould go wrong with you.

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: I will accomplish all I have revealed.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Come: let’s go drink! Choler makes me as dry as a dog.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt Will, Greene, and Shakebag. Michael remains.

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: Thus feeds the lamb securely on the down,
Whilst through the thicket of an arbor brake,
The hunger-bitten wolf o’erpries his haunt
And takes advantage to eat him up.
Ah, harmless Arden how, how hast thou misdone.
That thus thy gentle life is leveled at?
The many good turns that thou hast done to me
Now must I quittance with betraying thee:
I that should take the weapon in my hand
And buckler thee from ill-intending foes,
Do lead thee with a wicked, fraudful smile,
As unsuspected to the slaughterhouse.
So have I sworn to Mosby and my mistress:
So have I promised to the slaughtermen.
And should I not deal currently with them,
Their lawless rage would take revenge on me.
Tush, I will spurn at mercy for this once.
Let pity lodge where feeble women lie.
I am resolved: and Arden needs must die.

scene.scenelocation: Arden and Franklin’s home in Aldersgate, London.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: No, Franklin, no! If fear or stormy threats.
If love of me, or care of womanhood,
If fear of God, or common speech of men,
Who mangle credit with their wounding words,
And couch dishonor as dishonor buds,
Might join repentance in her wanton thoughts,
No question, then, but she would turn the leaf
And sorrow for her dissolution.
But she is rooted in her wickedness:
Perverse and stubborn, not to be reclaimed.
Good counsel is to her as rain to weeds
And reprehension makes her vice to grow,
As Hydra’s head that perished by decay.
Her faults methink are painted in my face
For every searching eye to overread.
And Mosby’s name, a scandal unto mine,
Is deeply trenched in my blushing brow.
Ah, Franklin, Franklin, when I think on this,
My heart’s grief rends my other powers
Worse than the conflict at the hour of death.

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: Gentle Arden, leave this sad lament.
She will amend, and so your griefs will cease:
Or else she’ll die, and so your sorrows end.
If neither of these two do haply fall,
Yet let your comfort be that others bear
Your woes twice doubled all with patience.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: My house is irksome: there I cannot rest.

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: Then stay with me in London: go not home.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Then that base Mosby doth usurp my room,
And makes his triumph of my being thence.
At home, or not at home, where’er I be,
Here, here it lies. Ah, Franklin, here it lies.
That will not out till wretched Arden dies.

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: Forget your griefs awhile, here comes your man

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: What o’clock is’t, sirrah?

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: Almost ten.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: See, see how runs away the weary time!
Come, Master Franklin, shall we go to bed?

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: I pray you go before: I’ll follow you.
Ah, what a hell is fretful jealousy?
What pity-moaning words, what deep-fetched sighs,
What grievous groans, and overlading woes
Accompanies this gentle gentleman!
Now will he shake his care-oppressèd head.
Then fix his sad eyes on the sullen earth,
Ashamed to gaze upon the open world.
Now will he cast his eyes up towards the heavens
Looking that ways for redress of wrong.
Sometimes he seeketh to beguile his grief,
And tells a story with his careful tongue.
Then comes his wife’s dishonor in his thoughts.
And in the middle cutteth off his tale,
Pouring fresh sorrow on his weary limbs.
So woebegone, so inly charged with woe:
Was never any lived and bore it so.

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: My master would desire you come to bed.

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: Is he himself already in his bed?

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: He is and fain would have the light away.—
Conflicting thoughts encamped in my breast
Awake me with the echo of their strokes
And I, a judge to censure either side,
Can give to neither wished victory.
My master’s kindness pleads to me for life
With just demand and I must grant it him.
My mistress she hath forced me with an oath,
For Susan’s sake, the which I may not break,
For that is nearer than a master’s love.
That grim-faced fellow, pitiless Black Will
And Shakebag, stern in bloody stratagem —
Two rougher ruffians never lived in Kent —
Have sworn my death if I infringe my vow,
A dreadful thing to be considered of.
Methinks I see them with their boltered hair,
Staring and grinning in thy gentle face,
And in their ruthless hands, their daggers drawn,
Insulting o’er thee with a peck of oaths,
Whilst thou, submissive, pleading for relief,
Art mangled by their ireful instruments.
Methinks I hear them ask where Michael is
And pitiless Black Will cries. “Stab the slave.
The peasant will detect the tragedy.”
The wrinkles in his foul, death-threatening face
Gapes open wide, like graves to swallow men.
My death to him is but a merriment,
And he will murder me to make him sport.
He comes, he comes! Ah, Master Franklin help!
Call up the neighbors or we are but dead!

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: What dismal outcry calls me from my rest?

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: What hath occasioned such a fearful cry?
Speak, Michael! Hath any injured thee?

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: Nothing sir, but as I fell asleep.
Upon the threshold leaning to the stairs,
I had a fearful dream that troubled me:
And in my slumber thought I was beset
With murderer thieves that came to rifle me.
My trembling joints witness my inward fear.
I crave your pardons for disturbing you.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: So great a cry for nothing, I ne’er heard.
What, are the doors fast locked and all things safe?

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: I cannot tell, I think I locked the doors.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: I like not this, but I’ll go see myself.
Ne’er trust me, but the doors were all unlocked!
This negligence not half contenteth me.
Get you to bed: and if you love my favor,
Let me have no more such pranks as these.
Come, Master Franklin, let us go to bed.

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: Ay, by my faith, the air is very cold.
Michael, farewell: I pray thee dream no more.

scene.scenelocation: Aldersgate, London. The street outside Arden’s and Franklin’s house.

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: Black night hath hid the pleasures of the day.
And sheeting darkness overhangs the earth,
And with the black fold of her cloudy robe
Obscure us from the eyesight of the world
In which sweet silence such as we triumph.
The lazy minutes linger on their time.
Loth to give due audit to the hour
Till in the watch our purpose be complete.
And Arden sent to everlasting night.
Greene, get you gone, and linger here about,
And at some hour hence, come to us again,
Where we will give you instance of his death.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Speed to my wish whose will soe’er says no:
And so I’ll leave you for an hour or two.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: I tell thee Shakebag, would this thing were done.
I am so heavy that I can scarce go:
This drowsiness in me bodes little good.

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: How now Will, become a precisian?
Nay, then let’s go sleep when bugs and fears
Shall kill our courages with their fancy’s work.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Why, Shakebag, thou mistakes me much
And wrongs me too in telling me of fear.
Were’t not a serious thing we go about
It should be slipped till I had fought with thee,
To let thee know I am no coward, I:
I tell thee, Shakebag, thou abusest me.

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: Why thy speech bewrayed an inly kind of fear
And savored of a weak, relenting spirit.
Go forward now in that we have begun:
And afterwards attempt me when thou dar’st.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: And if I do not, heaven cut me off.
But let that pass, and show me to this house
Where thou shalt see I’ll do as much as Shakebag.

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: This is the door. But soft, methinks ’tis shut.
The villain Michael hath deceived us.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Soft, let me see, Shakebag. ‘Tis shut indeed.
Knock with thy sword, perhaps the slave will hear.

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: It will not be. The white-livered peasant
Is gone to bed and laughs us both to scorn.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: And he shall buy his merriment as dear,
As ever coistrel bought so little sport.
Ne’er let this dagger help me when I need
But rust and canker after I have sworn
If I, the next time that I meet the hind.
Lop not away his leg, his arm, or both.

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: And let me never draw a dagger more,
Nor prosper in the twilight, cock-shut light,
When I would fleece the wealthy passenger,
But lie and languish in a loathsome den,
Hated and spit at by the goers-by,
And in that death may die unpitièd
If I, the next time that I meet the slave,
Cut not the nose from off the coward’s face,
And trample on it for this villainy.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Come, let’s go seek out Greene: I know he’ll swear.

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: He were a villain and he would not swear.
’Twould make a peasant swear amongst his boys,
That ne’er durst say before but “yea” and “no”
To be thus flouted of a coisterel.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Shakebag, let’s seek out Greene, and in the morning
At the ale-house butting Arden’s house,
Watch the outcoming of that prick-eared cur,
And then let me alone to handle him.

scene.scenelocation: Arden and Franklin’s home in Aldersgate, London.

stagedir.dir: The next morning. Arden, Franklin, and Michael enter.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Sirrah, get you back to Billingsgate
And learn what time the tide will serve our turn.
Come to us in Paul’s. First, go make the bed,
And afterwards go harken for the flood.
Come, Master Franklin, you shall go with me.
This night I dreamed that being in a park,
A toil was pitched to overthrow the deer
And I, upon a little rising hill,
Stood whistly watching for the herd’s approach.
Even there, methoughts, a gentle slumber took me
And summoned all my parts to sweet repose.
But in the pleasure of this golden rest
An ill-thewed foster had removed the toil
And rounded me with that beguiling home, is
Which late, methought, was pitched to cast the deer.
With that he blew an evil-sounding horn.
And at the noise another herdman came
With falchion drawn, and bent it at my breast.
Crying aloud, “Thou art the game we seek!”
With this I waked and trembled every joint,
Like one obscured in a little bush
That sees a lion foraging about.
And when the dreadful forest king is gone,
He pries about with timorous suspect
Throughout the thorny casements of the brake.
And will not think his person dangerless,
But quakes and shivers though the cause be gone.
So trust me, Franklin, when I did awake
I stood in doubt whether I waked or no,
Such great impression took this fond surprise.
God grant this vision bedeem me any good.

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: This fantasy doth rise from Michael’s fear,
Who being awaked with the noise he made,
His troubled senses yet could take no rest:
And this, I warrant you, procured your dream.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: It may be so, God frame it to the best.
But oftentimes my dreams presage too true.

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: To such as note their nightly fantasies,
Some one in twenty may incur belief.
But use it not: tis but a mockery.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Come, Master Franklin, we’ll now walk in Paul’s
And dine together at the ordinary.
And by my man’s direction draw to the quay
And with the tide go down to Faversham.
Say, Master Franklin, shall it not be so?

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: At your good pleasure, sir: I’ll bear you company.

scene.scenelocation: Aldersgate, London. The street outside Arden’s and Franklin’s house.

stagedir.dir: Michael enters at one door, leaving the house. Then Greene, Will, and Shakebag enter at another door.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Draw, Shakebag, for here’s that villain Michael.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: First, Will, let’s hear what he can say.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Speak, milksop slave, and never after speak!

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: For God’s sake sirs, let me excuse myself!
For hear I swear by heaven and earth and all,
I did perform the outmost of my task
And left the doors unbolted and unlocked.
But see the chance: Franklin and my master
Were very late conferring in the porch.
And Franklin left his purse there where he sat,
With a sum of gold in it, as he said.
Being in bed, he did bethink himself,
And coming down, he found the doors unshut.
He locked the gates and brought away the keys.
For which offense my master ’rated me.
But now I am going to see what flood it is,
For with the tide my master will away,
Where you may front him well on Rainham Down,
A place well-fitting such a stratagem.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Your excuse hath somewhat mollified my choler.—
Why now, Greene, ’tis better now nor e’er it was.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: But, Michael, is this true?

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: As true as I report it to be true.

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: Then, Michael, this shall be your penance:
To feast us all at the Salutation,
Where we will plot our purpose throughly.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: And Michael, you shall bear no news of this tide
Because they two may be in Rainham Down down before your master.

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: Why I’ll agree to anything you’ll have me:
So you will accept of my company.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Disturbèd thoughts drives me from company
And dries my marrow with their watchfulness,
Continual trouble of my moody brain
Feebles my body by excess of drink
And nips me, as the bitter north-east wind
Doth check the tender blossoms in the spring.
Well fares the man, howe’er his cates do taste,
That tables not with foul suspicion:
And he but pines amongst his delicates
Whose troubled mind is stuffed with discontent.
My golden time was when I had no gold.
Though then I wanted, yet I slept secure:
My daily toil begat me night’s repose,
My night’s repose made daylight fresh to me.
But since I climbed the top bough of the tree
And sought to build my nest among the clouds,
Each gentle starry gale doth shake my bed
And makes me dread my downfall to the earth.
But whither doth contemplation carry me?
The way I seek to find where pleasure dwells
Is hedged behind me that I cannot back
But needs must on although to danger’s gate.
Then, Arden, perish thou by that decree,
For Greene doth till the land and weed thee up
To make my harvest nothing but pure corn.
And for his pains I’ll raise him up awhile
And after smother him to have his wax.
Such bees as Greene must never live to sting.
Then is there Michael and the painter too,
Chief actors to Arden’s overthrow,
Who, when they shall see me sit in Arden’s seat.
They will insult upon me for my meed
Or fright me by detecting of his end.
I’ll none of that, for I can cast a bone
To make these curs pluck out each other’s throat,
And then am I sole ruler of mine own.
Yet Mistress Arden lives: but she’s myself,
And holy church rites makes us two but one.
But what for that I may not trust you, Alice?
You have supplanted Arden for my sake,
And will extinguish me to plant another.
‘Tis fearful sleeping in a serpent’s bed
And I will cleanly rid my hands of her.

stagedir.dir: Alice, returning from church, enters carrying a prayerbook.

speech.line: But here she comes and I must flatter her—
How now, Alice? What, sad and passionate?
Make me partaker of thy pensiveness:
Fire divided burns with lesser force.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: But I will damn that fire in my breast:
Till by the force thereof my part consume.
Ah, Mosby!

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Such deep pathaires like to a cannon’s burst
Discharged against a ruinated wall,
Breaks my relenting heart in thousand pieces.
Ungentle Alice, thy sorrow is my sore:
Thou knowst it well and ’tis thy policy
To forge distressful looks, to wound a breast
Where lies a heart that dies where thou art sad:
It is not love that loves to anger love.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: It is not love that loves to murder love.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: How mean you that?

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Thou knowst how dearly Arden lovèd me.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: And then?

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: And then — conceal the rest, for ’tis too bad,
Lest that my words be carried with the wind
And published in the world to both our shames.
I pray thee, Mosby, let our springtime wither:
Our harvest else will yield but loathsome weeds.
Forget, I pray thee, what hath passed betwixt us.
For now I blush and tremble at the thoughts.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: What, are you changed?

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Ay, to my former happy life again,
From title of an odious strumpet’s name
To honest Arden’s wife, not Arden’s honest wife.
Ha, Mosby, ’tis thou hast rifled me of that,
And made me sland’rous to all my kin.
Even in my forehead is thy name engraven,
A mean artificer, that low-born name.
I was bewitched. Woe worth the hapless hour
And all the causes that enchanted me.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Nay, if thou ban, let me breath curses forth,
And if you stand so nicely at your fame,
Let me repent the credit I have lost.
I have neglected matters of import
That would have stated me above thy state,
Forslowed advantages, and spurned at time.
Ay, Fortune’s right hand Mosby hath forsook
To take a wanton giglot by the left.
I left the marriage of an honest maid,
Whose dowry would have weighed down all thy wealth,
Whose beauty and demeanor far exceeded thee.
This certain good I lost for changing bad
And wrapped my credit in thy company.
I was bewitched — that is no theme of thine! —
And thou unhallowed hast enchanted me.
But I will break thy spells and exorcisms,
And put another sight upon these eyes
That showed my heart a raven for a dove.
Thou art not fair, I viewed thee not till now:
Thou art not kind: till now I knew thee not.
And now the rain hath beaten off thy gilt,
Thy worthless copper shows thee counterfeit.
It grieves me not to see how foul thou art,
But mads me that ever I thought thee fair.
Go, get thee gone, a copesmate for thy slaves!
I am too good to be thy favorite.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Ay, now I see, and too soon find it true,
Which often hath been told me by my friends,
That Mosby loves me not but for my wealth.
Which, too incredulous I ne’er believed.
Nay, hear me speak, Mosby, a word or two:
I’ll bite my tongue if it speak bitterly.
Look on me, Mosby, or I’ll kill myself.
Nothing shall hide me from thy stormy look.
If thou cry war, there is no peace for me.
I will do penance for offending thee
And burn this prayerbook, where I here use
The holy word that had converted me.
See, Mosby, I will tear away the leaves,

stagedir.dir: She tears out leaves from the prayerbook.

speech.line: And all the leaves, and in this golden cover
Shall thy sweet phrases and thy letters dwell:
And thereon will I chiefly meditate,
And hold no other sect but such devotion.
Wilt thou not look? Is all thy love o’erwhelmed?
Wilt thou not hear? What malice stops thine ears?
Why speaks thou not? What silence ties thy tongue?
Thou hast been sighted as the eagle is,
And heard as quickly as the fearful hare.
And spoke as smoothly as an orator.
When I have bid thee hear or see or speak,
And art thou sensible in none of these?
Weigh all thy good turns with this little fault,
And I deserve not Mosby’s muddy looks.
A fount once troubled is not thickened still:
Be clear again, I’ll ne’er more trouble thee.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: O, no, I am a base artificer:
My wings are feathered for a lowly flight.
Mosby? Fie, no! Not for a thousand pound.
Make love to you? Why, ’tis unpardonable:
We beggars must not breathe where gentles are.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Sweet Mosby is as gentle as a king.
And I too blind to judge him otherwise.
Flowers do sometimes spring in fallow lands,
Weeds in gardens, roses grow on thorns:
So whatsoe’er my Mosby’s father was,
Himself is valued gentle by his worth.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Ah, how you women can insinuate,
And clear a trespass with your sweet-set tongue.
I will forget this quarrel, gentle Alice,
Provided I’ll be tempted so no more.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Then with thy lips seal up this new-made match.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Soft, Alice, for here comes somebody.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: How now, Bradshaw, what’s the news with you?

speech.speaker: BRAD.
speech.line: I have little news but here’s a letter
That Master Greene importuned me to give you.

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Go in, Bradshaw, call for a cup of beer.
‘Tis almost suppertime: thou shalt stay with us.

line.recite: “We have missed of our purpose at London, but shall perform it by the way. We thank our neighbor Bradshaw.

speech.line: How likes my love the tenor of this letter?

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: Well, were his date complete and expired!

speech.speaker: ALICE.
speech.line: Ah, would it were! Then comes my happy hour:
Till then my bliss is mixed with bitter gall.
Come, let us in to shun suspicion.

speech.speaker: MOSBY.
speech.line: I to the gates of death to follow thee.

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: Come, Will, see thy tools be in a readiness?
Is not thy powder dank, or will thy flint strike fire?

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Then ask me if my nose be on my face
Or whether my tongue be frozen in my mouth.
Zounds, here’s a coil!
You were best swear me on the intergatories
How many pistols I have took in hand,
Or whether I love the smell of gunpowder
Or dare abide the noise the dag will make.
Or will not wink at flashing of the fire.
I pray thee, Shakebag, let this answer thee:
That I have took more purses in this down
Than e’er thou handled’st pistols in thy life.

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: Ay, haply thou hast picked more in a throng.
But should I brag what booties I have took:
I think the overplus that’s more than thine
Would mount to a greater sum of money
Than either thou or all thy kin are worth.
Zounds, I hate them as I hate a toad
That carry a muscado in their tongue.
And scarce a hurting weapon in their hand.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: O, Greene, intolerable!
It is not for mine honor to bear this.
Why, Shakebag, I did serve the King at Boulogne
And thou canst brag of nothing that thou hast done.

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: Why, so can Jack of Faversham.
That swooned for a fillip on the nose,
When he that gave it him hollowed in his ear.
And he supposed a cannon bullet hit him.

stagedir.dir: Greene tries to keep the peace.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: I pray you, sirs, list to Aesop’s talk:
Whilst two stout dogs were striving for a bone,
There comes a cur and stole it from them both.
So while you stand striving on these terms of manhood,
Arden escapes us and deceives us all.

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: Why, he begun.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: And thou shalt find I’ll end.
I do but slip it until better time,
But if I do forget—

stagedir.dir: He kneels down and holds up his hands to heaven.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Well, take your fittest standings, and once more
Lime your twigs to catch this weary bird.
I’ll leave you, and at your dag’s discharge,
Make towards like the longing water-dog
That coucheth till the fowling-piece be off
Then seizeth on the prey with eager mood.
Ah, might I see him stretching forth his limbs
As I have seen them beat their wings ‘ere now.

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: Why, that thou shalt see if he come this way.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Yes, that he doth, Shakebag, I warrant thee.
But brawl not when I am gone in any case,
But, sirs, be sure to speed him when he comes:
And in that hope I’ll leave you for an hour.

stagedir.dir: Arden, Franklin, and Michael enter with horses.

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: ’Twere best that I went back to Rochester.
The horse halts downright: it were not good
He traveled in such pain to Faversham.
Removing of a shoe may happily help it.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Well, get you back to Rochester, but, sirrah, see
Ye overtake us ‘ere we come to Rainham Down,
For it will be very late ‘ere we get home.

speech.speaker: MICH.
speech.line: Ay, God he knows, and so doth Will and Shakebag.
That thou shalt never go further than that down,
And therefore have I pricked the horse on purpose,
Because I would not view the massacre.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Come, Master Franklin, onwards with your tale.

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: I assure you sir, you task me much.
A heavy blood is gathered at my heart
And, on the sudden, is my wind so short
As hindereth the passage of my speech.
So fierce a qualm yet ne’er assailed me.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Come, Master Franklin, let us go on softly.
The annoyance of the dust, or else some meat
You ate at dinner, cannot brook you.
I have been often so and soon amended.

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: Do you remember where my tale did leave?

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Ay, where the gentleman did check his wife.

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: She, being reprehended for the fact,
Witness produced that took her with the deed,
Her glove brought in, which there she left behind,
And many other assured arguments:
Her husband asked her whether it were not so.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Her answer then? I wonder how she looked
Having forsworn it with such vehement oaths
And at the instant so approved upon her.

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: First, did she cast her eyes down to the earth,
Watching the drops that fell amain from thence,
Then softly draws she forth her handkercher
And modestly she wipes her tear-stained face.
Then, hemmed she out,to clear her voice should seem,
And with a majesty addressed herself
To encounter all their accusations.
Pardon me, Master Arden, I can no more:
This fighting at my heart, makes short my wind.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Come, we are almost now at Rainham Down:
Your pretty tale beguiles the weary way.
I would you were in state to tell it out.

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: Stand close, Will, I hear them coming.

stagedir.dir: Lord Cheyne and his man enter.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Stand to it, Shakebag, and be resolute.

speech.speaker: CHEY.
speech.line: Is it so near night as it seems,
Or will this black-faced evening have a shower?
What, Master Arden, you are well met.
I have longed this fortnight’s day to speak with you:
You are a stranger, man, in the Isle of Sheppey.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Your honor’s always, bound to do you service.

speech.speaker: CHEY.
speech.line: Come you from London and ne’er a man with you?

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: My man’s coming after:
But here’s my honest friend that came along with me.

speech.speaker: CHEY.
speech.line: My Lord Protector’s man, I take you to be.

speech.speaker: FRANK.
speech.line: Ay, my good lord, and highly bound to you.

speech.speaker: CHEY.
speech.line: You and your friend come home and sup with me.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: I beseech your honor pardon me:
I have made a promise to a gentleman,
My honest friend, to meet him at my house.
The occasion is great, or else would I wait on you.

speech.speaker: CHEY.
speech.line: Will you come tomorrow and dine with me?
And bring your honest friend along with you:
I have diverse matters to talk with you about.

speech.speaker: ARDEN.
speech.line: Tomorrow we’ll wait upon your honor.

speech.speaker: CHEY.
speech.line: You, stay my horse at the top of the hill.
What, Black Will, for whose purse wait you?
Thou wilt be hanged in Kent when all is done.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Not hanged, God save your honor.
I am your beadsman, bound to pray for you.

speech.speaker: CHEY.
speech.line: I think thou ne’er said’st prayer in all thy life.
One of you give him a crown:
And, sirrah, leave this kind of life.
If thou be’st ’tainted for a penny matter,
And come in question surely thou wilt truss.
Come, Master Arden, let us be going:
Your way and mine lies four mile together.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt. Black Will and Shakebag remain.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: The devil break all your necks, at four miles end.
Zounds, I could kill myself for very anger!
His lordship chops me in, even when
My dag was leveled at his heart.
I would his crown were molten down his throat.

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: Arden, thou hast wondrous holy luck!
Did ever man escape as thou hast done?
Well, I’ll discharge my pistol at the sky,
For by this bullet, Arden might not die.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: What, is he down, is he dispatched?

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: Ay, in health towards Faversham, to shame us all.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: The devil he is. Why, sirs, how escaped he?

speech.speaker: SHAKE.
speech.line: When we were ready to shoot,
Comes my Lord Cheyne to prevent his death.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: The lord of heaven hath preserved him.

speech.speaker: WILL.
